resources.string: Panic Button will now disguise itself
I understand, set-up my trusted contacts now
I understand, write my message now
Panic Button is an emergency alert app for people at risk.
App disguises itself to avoid discovery
Alerts are sent via SMS every 5 minutes
Option to post alert to Twitter via SMS
3 ways to send an emergency alert
#1. The Emergency Alert button in Settings…
#2. From any button on the app’s disguise…
You can change your contacts or alert message from the app\'s Settings screen.
Alert is active and Sending every five minutes
Add up to three emergency contacts
Post alert to Twitter via SMS
To connect your phone to Twitter by SMS, send a text with the word START to:
We are only able to connect with phone service providers supported by Twitter.
Setting a pin helps secure the app, you must enter it to access the Settings screen hidden behind the calculator disguise. \n\nYou do not need to enter it to send an alert
Enter a four digit pin, something easy to remember - you cannot change it.
Please reinstall the application if you cannot remember your pin number
Do you want to save the changes?
Tap five times fast to send alert

Panic Button turns your mobile phone into a secret alarm so that your trusted contacts can respond quickly if you are in trouble.

Once you have set-off the 'Panic' alarm, your trusted three contacts will receive an SMS and a map link with your location every five minutes.

Panic Button is disguised so that aggressors cannot detect that the alarm has been set-off, helping to ensure your trusted contacts get critical updates about your location.

For Panic Button to help you when you need it the most, we recommend taking the time to create a security plan with your trusted contacts.

This training will show you how to use the app and offer security tips about creating a security plan.

The training will take approx. 10 minutes so make sure you are somewhere quiet and safe.

Enter a four digit pin, something easy to remember - you cannot change it.

This pin helps prevent unauthorized access to your settings.

You don't need this pin to send an emergency message.
Think first! Your trusted contacts should be people that you know personally and should be prepared and able to respond fast.\n\nQuestions to ask:
Think first! Your emergency message needs to clearly communicate that you need help in only a few words.\n\nQuestions to ask:
Think first! Your emergency message needs to clearly communicate that you need help in only a few words.
Who in my network can practically help me in an emergency?
Have I told these people they are a trusted contact?
Have I created a security plan so my trusted contacts know what to do when they receive the Panic message?
Think first! Your trusted contacts should be people that you know personally and should be prepared and able to respond fast.
Does your message work for all situations?
How often should you review and change it?
Would it be wise to create a code message with your contacts?
Do you want to enable GPS tracking from your phone settings so that your location sends with your emergency message?

Panic Button is disguised to protect you. From now on you will see a fake screen when you open the app. To get to your settings screen, hold down a button on the calculator and you will be asked to enter your pincode.
